headline.main: Beijing Continues Its March of Modernization

docs.snippet: The neighborhood of Gulou, which boasts a pair of brick towers dating back hundreds of years, is about to be turned into a polished tourist attraction.
docs.lead_paragraph: The neighborhood of Gulou, which boasts a pair of brick towers dating back hundreds of years, is about to be turned into a polished tourist attraction.

docs.abstract: Beijing Journal; Gulou, one of Beijing's oldest neighborhoods with towers dating back hundreds of years, will become a tourist attraction called Beijing Time Cultural City; preservationists are alarmed at loss of historically significant area, but many residents seem pleased that they will be compensated for their ramshackle homes; photos (M)

headline.main: Bulldozers Meet Historic Chinese Neighborhood, to Mixed Reaction

docs.snippet: An area that has towers dating back hundreds of years will become an attraction called Beijing Time Cultural City.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Li Bibo contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Mao slept here. So, too, did the imperial eunuchs who found themselves unemployed after China's last emperor was sent packing. For much of the last 700 years, however, the most prominent residents of the quarter just north of the Forbidden City have been a pair of massive brick towers whose drums and bells helped Beijing's citizenry keep track of the hour. More recently, those who reside in the neighborhood known as Gulou are anxiously counting the days until construction crews begin turning its 32 charmingly decrepit acres into a polished tourist attraction called Beijing Time Cultural City.

docs.snippet: Images from China's National Robot Competition, held in Beijing.
docs.lead_paragraph: The robots in these photos are being controlled by contestants in China's tenth annual National Robot Competition.

headline.main: A Grim Chapter in History Kept Closed

docs.snippet: While the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution is not a taboo subject in China per se, research and writings about it are strictly controlled, leaving many to wonder whether the truth will survive.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- On a day in late March, Zhang Dazhong, one of China's richest men, struggled to speak through tears as he addressed his assembled guests. ''My mother died 40 years ago this year, but I never held a decent memorial for her,'' Mr. Zhang said. On the stage about him, in the red-carpeted hall of a luxury hotel, were flowers and a large portrait of a woman in a white shirt, her hair in pigtails.

docs.abstract: China continues to suffer the downsides of its rampant economic growth, with new figures showing an increase in pollution in the air, tainted by coal-burning power plants; China remains world's most prodigious emitter of greenhouse gases; photo (M)

headline.main: As China's Economy Grows, Pollution Worsens Despite New Efforts to Control It

docs.snippet: China continues to suffer the downsides of its rampant economic growth, with new figures showing an increase in pollution in the air and along its waterways.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Lim Xin Hui and Xiyun Yang contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- China, the world's most prodigious emitter of greenhouse gas, continues to suffer the downsides of unbridled economic growth despite a raft of new environmental initiatives. The quality of air in Chinese cities is increasingly tainted by coal-burning power plants, grit from construction sites and exhaust from millions of new cars squeezing onto crowded roads, according to a government study issued this week. Other newly released figures show a jump in industrial accidents and an epidemic of pollution in waterways.

docs.abstract: Three men in China are sentenced to prison terms of 3 to 10 years for 'endangering state security' by helping maintain popular Uighur-language Web sites; sentences are latest indication that Beijing is intensifying its crackdown on any dissent that questions Chinese rule in Xinjiang (M)

headline.main: China Imprisons 3 Men Who Maintained Uighur Web Sites

docs.snippet: The sentences are the latest indication that Beijing is intensifying its crackdown on any dissent that questions Chinese rule in Xinjiang.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Zhang Jing contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Three men accused of ''endangering state security'' for their roles in maintaining popular Uighur-language Web sites have been sentenced to prison terms of 3 to 10 years, according to exile groups and court officials. The sentences, the outcome of a one-day trial last week, are the latest indication that Beijing is intensifying its crackdown on any dissent that questions Chinese rule in Xinjiang, the far western region where ethnic rioting last summer killed nearly 200 people, many of them Han Chinese whose growing numbers have stoked resentment among Uighurs.

docs.abstract: State-owned companies in China are bidding up prices on sprawling plots of land for big real estate projects unrelated to their core businesses; by driving up property prices state-owned companies, which are ultimately controlled by national government, are working at cross-purposes with central government's effort to keep China's real estate boom from becoming debt-ridden speculative bubble; records show that 82 percent of land auctions in Beijing this year have been won by state-owned companies outbidding private developers; critics say central government unwittingly propelled land frenzy by pushing huge $586 billion economic stimulus package in 2009 and encouraging state-owned banks to lend more aggressively; Beijing is now struggling to rein in credit without slowing nation's economy and regulators are trying to stop state banks from using clever maneuvers to secretly lend money to overly aggressive state-owned developers; photo; chart (M)

headline.main: State-Owned Bidders Fuel China's Land Boom

docs.snippet: Even as China tries to avoid a debt-driven real estate bubble, state-owned companies have been driving up prices by outbidding private developers for land.

byline.original: By DAVID BARBOZA; Bao Beibei and Chen Xiaoduan contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: WUHU, China -- The Anhui Salt Industry Corporation is a state-owned company that has 11,000 employees, access to government salt mines and a Communist Party boss. Now it has swaggered into a new line of business: real estate.

docs.abstract: China's bank workers, educated, organized and knowledgeable about Internet, have become unlikely agitators in past two years, staging protests in Beijing and provincial cities after being laid off; state-controlled banks have slashed payrolls and restructured to raise profitablilty and make themselves more attractive to outside investors; former employees, who strategize via online message boards and text messages and speak in code, have often been successful in outsmarting public security agents constantly on their trail; but their acts of defiance are never mentioned in state-run news media, and years of fruitless protests and economic hardship have taken toll; Renee Xia, international director of Chinese Human Rights Defenders, says workers are not going to succeed because the more organized they are, the more harsh government's reaction will be; photos (M)

headline.main: Laid Off by Banks in China, Workers Do Not Go Quietly

docs.snippet: Many employees who lost their jobs as state-run banks restructured are organizing to demand new jobs or compensation, but they face a daunting task.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Lim Xinhui contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- These are heady days for China's state-controlled banks. Last month, the Agricultural Bank of China made its stock market debut, bringing in $22 billion for the largest public offering ever. A sister government-run bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, now has the highest stock market value of any bank in the world. But the windfalls have created an unusual problem for China: white-collar unrest. A few days after the Agricultural Bank went public, dozens of former bank employees stealthily gathered outside the headquarters of the country's central bank. There, after distributing small Chinese flags, they quickly pulled on red and blue T-shirts that read, ''Protect the Rights of Downsized Bank Workers.'' By the time they had unfurled their protest banners, the game was over.

docs.snippet: China's voracious energy demands mean environmental disasters are very likely.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes statistics collide at just the right time to paint a picture. China's growing energy needs are resulting in a surge of industrial incidents, and there is little chance that the country's string of environmental catastrophes are likely to ebb anytime soon. It's been one month since the People's Republic suffered its worst ever oil spill. The disaster on July 16 came at a sensitive time for Beijing, as news emerged that China has surpassed the United States in energy consumption.
